addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

12 N
o
1590
M
r
Bodeley to my L. from
e Hagh.

page.lettertext:
fol.218r
May it please yo
r
good L. Having re-
commended, as I was willed, the cause of
Coronel Stuart
, to
e
General states
, they have
sent unto me a copie of
e Scottishe Ambassa-
do
rs
Proposition, and of their Answear ther-
unto: also a copie of their letters to
e
King
,
and to
e
Chancelo
r
of
Scotland
: whiche I
have sent yo
w
all together. Howbeit I do
suppose, that
e Ambassado
r
himself hath bin
w
t
yo
w
er this, and hath signified all by
worde of mouthe. Whiche I also thought by
him, to have written to yo
r
L. but that he
was not resolved, to take his jorney for
Eng-
land
, when he parted from
e Hage.
I am nowe assured by
e Greffier
of
e states, that their Answear to her
Ma
tie
is agreed upon, and written, and wanteth
nothing but deliverie: w
ch
, as he hath under-
stood, shall be made unto me. It
was thought er this, that
e Deputies appoin-
ted for England, should have taken their
voiage. But
Silla
e Pensioner of
Amster-
dam
, w
ch
was one of
e two, that was elected,
hath refused
e charge: wherupon they are to
seeke, howe their turne may be served.
Count Maurice
is nowe at
Utrecht
,
to take possession of his government: and
from thens he intendeth to visit
Overissell
.
Heere is every thing quiet, and for
ought I can perceave, there is nothing meant
to be exploited, but by the way of surprise.
fol.218v
For the Count hath had a long practise in hand,
upon
Shertogenbosch
: whiche he carieth very
secretly, and hath imparted it to none, but in
speciall confidence. There are in
e towne
it self, that have promised by a certain night,
to open suche a passage under grownde, by un-
dermining
e wales, as there shall be an en-
trance for sufficient troupes, to surprise the
place. I may have many suche secret oc-
casions, that would require a Cipher, whiche
I beseeche yo
r
L. to send me, if yo
w
thinke it
convenient. This day
e De-
putie of
e towne of
Geneva
, who hath sojor-
ned heere, sins his comming out of England,
is departed towardes
Hambourgh
: having
wholy receaved
e Collection of
e Provinces:
whiche amounteth to no more but 1300
li
ster
l
.
Having nothing els of any mo-
ment, I take my humble leave.
At
e Hage. N
o
12 1590.
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
